user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_lseek:
```c
int32 OS_lseek(osal_id_t filedes, int32 offset, uint32 whence)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Make sure the file descriptor is legit before using it */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericSeek_Impl(&token, offset, whence);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_lseek:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_GenericSeek_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, int32 offset, uint32 whence)
{
    int                             where;
    off_t                           os_result;
    int32                           retval;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    switch (whence)
    {
        case OS_SEEK_SET:
            where = SEEK_SET;
            break;
        case OS_SEEK_CUR:
            where = SEEK_CUR;
            break;
        case OS_SEEK_END:
            where = SEEK_END;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    os_result = lseek(impl->fd, (off_t)offset, where);
    if (os_result == (off_t)-1)
    {
        if (errno == ESPIPE)
        {
            /*
             * this means the user tried to seek on a pipe, socket,
             * or other fifo-like handle that doesn't support seeking.
             *
             * Use a different error code to differentiate from an
             * error involving a bad whence/offset
             */
            retval = OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * Most likely the "whence" and/or "offset" combo was not valid.
             */
            OS_DEBUG("lseek: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            retval = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * convert value to int32 type for returning to caller.
         * Note that this could potentially overflow an int32
         * for a large file seek.
         */
        retval = (int32)os_result;
    }

    return retval;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No explicit compiler language extensions were found in the provided code fragments. I looked for common, documented compiler extensions such as identifiers beginning with __ (e.g. __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, __extension__), GCC/Clang statement-expressions ({ ...; }) and ({ ... }) usage, typeof, nested functions, inline assembly, pragmas that are compiler-specific, or other non-standard syntax. The code only uses standard C constructs (functions, typedefs, casts), standard integer typedefs (int32_t/uint32_t), and POSIX library calls (lseek, strerror, errno) which are library/API usage rather than language/compiler extensions. Note: some identifiers in the code are macros (for example OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and OS_DEBUG) whose definitions were not provided. Their usage in this code does not itself demonstrate a language extension; if those macro definitions contain compiler-specific extensions then those definitions would need to be examined, but they are not present in the supplied fragments, so they cannot be reported here.
